Sure! Here are some commonly used metadata standards that work well for different types of digital collections:

1. Dublin Core: This metadata standard is widely used and works well for a wide range of digital collections, including image, audio, video, and text collections. It is a simple, core set of elements that are commonly used for describing a variety of resources.

2. Metadata Object Description Schema (MODS): MODS is used in libraries, archives, and museums to describe a wide range of resources, including textual materials, audio, and video recordings, digital images, and maps. It provides a more specialized set of elements and can accommodate more complex descriptions.

3. Metadata Encoding and Transmission Standard (METS): METS is a flexible metadata standard designed to capture metadata at the object or file level, making it particularly useful for digital collections that contain many separate files. It can be used for a wide range of content types, including text, image, video, and audio.

4. Encoded Archival Description (EAD): EAD is designed to describe archival collections and provides a structured way to describe the hierarchical relationships between materials. It uses XML-based encoding, making it easy to integrate with other systems.

5. PREMIS: PREMIS is a metadata standard designed specifically for digital preservation, providing information about the provenance, preservation, and authenticity of digital objects. It can be used for a wide range of file formats, including text, images, audio, and video.

These are just a few examples of metadata standards that work well for different types of digital collections. The choice of metadata standard will depend on the type of materials in your collection and the level of complexity in describing those materials.
